poem:
**Life under Labour**

Houses, like dreams,
stacked on narrow streets—
a promise
piled high.
Walls,
pressed close as worries,
hold bodies
in cramp and quiet.
Yet from this,
a breath,
a slender beam 
of hope—
to carve a corner
for ourselves,
a slender sigh.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Labour plans to build 1.5m homes – will that help Britons struggling for good housing? Labour appears poised to win a historic election victory on 4 July. In the series Life under Labour we look at Keir Starmer’s five key political missions. We ask what is at stake and whether he can deliver the change the country is crying out for. * * * ‘We have no space for ourselves, no space to think –". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
